distribution.text: Copyright Â© Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
Updated ntp packages that fix several security issues are now available
for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having Important security
impact. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which
gives a detailed severity rating, is available from the CVE link in the
References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The Network Time Protocol (NTP) is used to synchronize a computer's time
with a referenced time source.

Multiple buffer overflow flaws were discovered in ntpd's crypto_recv(),
ctl_putdata(), and configure() functions. A remote attacker could use
either of these flaws to send a specially crafted request packet that could
crash ntpd or, potentially, execute arbitrary code with the privileges of
the ntp user. Note: the crypto_recv() flaw requires non-default
configurations to be active, while the ctl_putdata() flaw, by default, can
only be exploited via local attackers, and the configure() flaw requires
additional authentication to exploit. (CVE-2014-9295)

It was found that ntpd automatically generated weak keys for its internal
use if no ntpdc request authentication key was specified in the ntp.conf
configuration file. A remote attacker able to match the configured IP
restrictions could guess the generated key, and possibly use it to send
ntpdc query or configuration requests. (CVE-2014-9293)

It was found that ntp-keygen used a weak method for generating MD5 keys.
This could possibly allow an attacker to guess generated MD5 keys that
could then be used to spoof an NTP client or server. Note: it is
recommended to regenerate any MD5 keys that had explicitly been generated
with ntp-keygen; the default installation does not contain such keys).
(CVE-2014-9294)

A missing return statement in the receive() function could potentially
allow a remote attacker to bypass NTP's authentication mechanism.
(CVE-2014-9296)

All ntp users are advised to upgrade to this updated package, which
contains backported patches to resolve these issues. After installing the
update, the ntpd daemon will restart automatically.
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Use of Cryptographically Weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)

notes.text: It was found that ntpd automatically generated weak keys for its internal use if no ntpdc request authentication key was specified in the ntp.conf configuration file. A remote attacker able to match the configured IP restrictions could guess the generated key, and possibly use it to send ntpdc query or configuration requests.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ntp: automatic generation of weak default key in config_auth()
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata 
relevant to your system have been applied.

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use the 
Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

Issue these commands to explicitly generate a strong key and add it to the
ntpd configuration:

    echo trustedkey 65535 >> /etc/ntp.conf
    printf "65535\tM\t%s\n" $(tr -cd a-zA-Z0-9 < /dev/urandom | head -c 16) >> /etc/ntp/keys

The generated key has about 95 bits of entropy.

vulnerabilities.title: ntp: automatic generation of weak default key in config_auth()

cwe.name: Use of Cryptographically Weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)

notes.text: It was found that ntp-keygen used a weak method for generating MD5 keys. This could possibly allow an attacker to guess generated MD5 keys that could then be used to spoof an NTP client or server. Note: it is recommended to regenerate any MD5 keys that had explicitly been generated with ntp-keygen; the default installation does not contain such keys.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ntp: ntp-keygen uses weak random number generator and seed when generating MD5 keys
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata 
relevant to your system have been applied.

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use the 
Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: ntp: ntp-keygen uses weak random number generator and seed when generating MD5 keys

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

notes.text: Multiple buffer overflow flaws were discovered in ntpd's crypto_recv(), ctl_putdata(), and configure() functions. A remote attacker could use either of these flaws to send a specially crafted request packet that could crash ntpd or, potentially, execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the ntp user. Note: the crypto_recv()  flaw requires non default configurations to be active, while the ctl_putdata() flaw, by default, can only be exploited via local attackers, and the configure() flaw requires additional authentication to exploit.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ntp: Multiple buffer overflows via specially-crafted packets
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata 
relevant to your system have been applied.

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use the 
Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

Add these lines (included by default starting with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5) to the configuration file /etc/ntp.conf:

    restrict default kod nomodify notrap nopeer noquery
    restrict -6 default kod nomodify notrap nopeer noquery
    restrict 127.0.0.1 
    restrict -6 ::1

This restricts server-type functionality to localhost.  If ntpd needs to perform time service for specific hosts and networks, you have to list them with suitable restrict statements.

vulnerabilities.title: ntp: Multiple buffer overflows via specially-crafted packets

cwe.name: Detection of Error Condition Without Action

notes.text: A missing return statement in the receive() function could potentially allow a remote attacker to bypass NTP's authentication mechanism.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ntp: receive() missing return on error
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This issue did not affect the versions of ntpd as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4 and 5.  It has been addressed in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7 via RHSA-2014:2024.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata 
relevant to your system have been applied.

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use the 
Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at 
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Remove or comment out all configuration directives beginning with the crypto keyword in your ntp.conf file.

vulnerabilities.title: ntp: receive() missing return on error
